G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: NOW COMES the Plaintiff, Jessica Thompson, and respectfully submits this Complaint for Modification of Custody Order pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and the rules and case law governing custody modifications in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.proposition: The Defendant has unilaterally enrolled the minor children in extracurricular activities that conflict with the Plaintiff's scheduled parenting time, without consulting or seeking her agreement in violation of the shared legal custody order as articulated in *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981) (holding that shared legal custody requires meaningful communication and collaboration between parents).
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.support_reasoning: The case does not involve shared legal custody or decision‑making conflicts over extracurricular activities. Instead, the court affirms an award of sole custody to the mother and explains why joint custody (which it equates with joint decision‑making) is inappropriate given the parties’ inability to cooperate. While the opinion discusses that joint custody requires cooperation and joint decision‑making, it does not articulate or enforce any rule that a parent with shared legal custody must obtain the other parent’s agreement before enrolling children in activities, so it does not support the specific proposition cited.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.relevant_excerpt: “Joint custody is synonymous with joint decision making and a common desire to promote the children’s best interests. ‘It is understandable, therefore, that joint custody is encouraged primarily as a voluntary alternative for relatively stable, amicable parents behaving in mature civilized fashion,’ … ‘Although complete agreement between parents to implement joint custody may not be necessary,’ in order to be effective ‘joint custody requires two capable parents with some degree of respect for one another’s abilities as parents, together with a willingness and ability to work together to reach results on major decisions…’”

*Stevens v. Stevens*, 337 Mass. 625 (195.proposition: The Defendant has created conflict and confusion for the children by blaming the Plaintiff when she cannot accommodate changed schedules, causing the children emotional distress in violation of the best interests standard established in *Stevens v. Stevens*, 337 Mass. 625 (1958).
*Stevens v. Stevens*, 337 Mass. 625 (195.support_reasoning: The case applies the general ‘welfare of the child is the controlling consideration’ standard in deciding a change of custody, but it does not address parental conduct involving schedule changes, blame-shifting, or creating emotional conflict for children. There is no discussion of a parent blaming the other for schedule issues, nor any specific holding about such behavior constituting a violation of the child’s best interests. Thus, citing this case for that particular proposition is inaccurate and overstates what Stevens actually held.
*Stevens v. Stevens*, 337 Mass. 625 (195.relevant_excerpt: "It is well settled that the welfare of the child is the controlling consideration and custody is not to be awarded or changed to discipline either party. Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555. ... In the new circumstances of the parents it was not an unreasonable conclusion that the daughter would be better off in the libellant’s family."

*Doe v. Doe No. 1*, 421 Mass. 221 (1995).proposition: The Defendant has disparaged the Plaintiff in front of the minor children, calling her “selfish” and asserting that she “doesn’t really love” them, in violation of the spirit of the May 10, 2022 order and the principle that parents must foster loving relationships with both parents, as emphasized in *Doe v. Doe No. 1*, 421 Mass. 221 (1995).
*Doe v. Doe No. 1*, 421 Mass. 221 (1995).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the Fourth Amendment and the common-law knock-and-announce rule in the context of a criminal search and seizure. It does not involve family law, custody, or any principle about parents fostering loving relationships with both parents or refraining from disparagement in front of children. Thus, citing this case for that parenting/custody proposition is inaccurate and unsupported by the opinion’s holding or reasoning.
*Doe v. Doe No. 1*, 421 Mass. 221 (1995).relevant_excerpt: "The knock and announce rule, requiring that the police announce their presence and purpose, is a common law rule in Massachusetts. Commonwealth v. Cundriff, 382 Mass. 137, 146 (1980), cert. denied, 451 U.S. 973 (1981). The policies underlying it are (1) to decrease the potential for violence, (2) to protect privacy, and (3) to prevent unnecessary damage to homes."

*Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608 (198.proposition: This is consistent with *Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608 (1987), which highlights the significance of children’s emotional and physical welfare in custody determinations.
*Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames custody as governed by the children’s best interests, and the court’s analysis focuses on factors tied to the children’s emotional and physical welfare—such as stability, adaptation to school and community, emotional impact of relocation, sibling relationships, and psychological reports. The court affirms custody to the mother based on these welfare-centered considerations, so the case is properly cited for the principle that children’s emotional and physical welfare are central in custody determinations.
*Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608 (198.relevant_excerpt: “Finally, Anthony maintains that the grant of custody of Rosemary and Tony to Sonja was wrong. A Probate Court judge must settle custody in a manner that advances the best interests of the children. … As concerns Rosemary’s custody, the judge’s decision has considerable support. She has lived with her mother since her parents’ separation in 1979. … Tony… has adapted well to his new school in Amherst, and has weathered the dissension between his parents. … Many of the reasons why Rosemary’s interests are better served by staying with her mother apply equally to Tony.”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The current custody arrangement is no longer in the best interests of the children, as the Plaintiff’s ability to make decisions and safeguard their emotional security is hindered by the Defendant’s actions in direct conflict with the principles set forth in *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a *modification* of an existing custody arrangement based on a parent’s impaired decision‑making and safeguarding of the children’s emotional security due to the other parent’s actions. *Custody of Kali* is an initial custody determination between unmarried parents, not a modification case, and it does not address when a current arrangement becomes no longer in the children’s best interests because of a parent’s impaired ability to make decisions. Instead, it affirms use of the best‑interests standard and emphasizes stability and continuity in existing satisfactory arrangements. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement, and contrary to the child’s best interest to disrupt it. Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.”

*Gilbert v. Gilbert*, 73 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Enforce a requirement for both parents to refrain from disparaging the other parent in the presence of the children, consistent with *Gilbert v. Gilbert*, 73 Mass. App. Ct. 256 (2008).
*Gilbert v. Gilbert*, 73 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: This opinion is a Massachusetts criminal case about jurisdiction, venue, and elements of rape; it does not involve family law, custody, or parenting plans. There is no discussion of parental non-disparagement provisions or any requirement that parents refrain from disparaging each other in the presence of their children. The citation to Gilbert in this text is to Commonwealth v. Gilbert, 366 Mass. 18 (1974), a different case, and even that relates only to criminal jurisdiction, not parenting conduct orders.
*Gilbert v. Gilbert*, 73 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Accord Commonwealth v. DiMarzo, 364 Mass. 669, 671 (1974) (‘With reference to the question of jurisdiction, there can be no doubt that the judge had no power to try the defendant for crimes committed out of State’); Commonwealth v. Gilbert, 366 Mass. 18, 28 (1974) (the jurisdiction of a Massachusetts court depends on ‘[w]hether a criminal act occurred within the territorial boundaries of the Commonwealth’).”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The facts detailed above satisfy this standard, consistent with precedents such as *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006) and *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981).
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The proposition just says that "the facts detailed above satisfy this standard, consistent with" Mason and Bouchard, without specifying what standard is meant or what the above facts are. Mason v. Coleman does clearly articulate the best‑interests standard for removal in a joint physical custody context and applies that standard to deny removal on its own facts, but nothing in the quoted opinion shows that it endorses some generic conclusion that unspecified "facts detailed above" would satisfy that standard. Without knowing the referenced facts or precise standard, we cannot say Mason affirmatively supports that proposition.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that in such a situation ‘cause shown’ pursuant to G. L. c. 208, § 30, means a showing that removal is in the ‘best interests’ of the children taking into account all the circumstances and weighing the factors as described below. On the facts in this case, the judge appropriately considered the ‘best interests’ of the children, and did not abuse her discretion in concluding that removal of the children would not serve their best interests.”

*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: The facts detailed above satisfy this standard, consistent with precedents such as *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006) and *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981).
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Bouchard does not say that any particular set of facts “satisfies” a standard; instead it vacates a custody award because the judge failed to make adequate findings and to apply the proper ‘best interests of the child’ criteria. The case stands for the need to base custody decisions on the child’s welfare and to articulate all relevant factors, not for the proposition that some new or described facts meet that standard. Using Bouchard to assert that the facts at issue “satisfy this standard” overstates what the opinion holds.
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. … Even assuming that the father has violated G. L. c. 272, § 16, we think that under the decided cases the award of custody cannot be sustained solely on that ground, apart from any relationship to the ‘welfare of the child.’ … On rehearing, the findings should examine the relative advantages of the respective parental environments.”
